Thai is member of the

, which is, with minor differences in vocabulary aside, virtually identical to Lao.
Thai is a

language with five tones: Mid, Low, Falling, High, and Rising. Meanings can change critically based on the tone, but Thais are fairly used to hearing foreigners mangle their language and can often work out the correct tone based on context. Try not to inflect your sentences; in particular, any questions should be pronounced as flat statements, without the rising intonation ("...yes?") typical to English questions.

The Thai written language is essentially alphabetic, but notoriously difficult to read due to a profusion of 44 consonants (many redundant), complicated tone and vowel signage around consonants and a complete lack of spaces between words.

Thai distinguishes between
("with a puff of air") and

("without a puff of air") consonants. Unaspirated consonants exist in English too, but never alone: compare the sound of 'p' in "pot" (aspirated) and "spot" (unaspirated). Many English speakers find it helpful to pronounce an imperceptible little "m" in front to 'stop' the puff.

In Thai romanized with the Royal Thai General System (used on Wikivoyage), the distinction is usually represented by writing aspirated consonants with "h" and unaspirated ones without it. In particular, "ph" represents a hard aspirated 'p' and
a soft 'f', and
is thus pronounced "Poo-ket". Likewise, "th" is a hard aspirated 't' and hence

is pronounced "Tie-land".

Other systems of romanization may use 'bp', 'dt' and 'g' for the unaspirated sounds, and 'p', 't', and 'k' for the aspirated sounds. This is not used in this guide.

Pronouns are often omitted if it's clear from the context who is doing what.
Note that that the polite suffix ครับ
(for men) and ค่ะ
(for women) can and should be attached to all phrases when talking with strangers. The suffix depends solely on your gender.  Also note that the pronoun for "I" is ผม
for men and ดิฉัน

for women.

When addressing people, คุณ
is a safe, respectful all-purpose equivalent to "Mr/Ms/Mrs".  People you're familiar with can be addressed as พี่
(if they are elders) or น้อง
(if they are younger).  These are always used with first names, so your business partner Supachai Sakulwattana is
and your secretary Nipaporn Khampolsiri is

.  All Thais also have short nicknames, but these are only used informally.

The closer two friends are, the less often you will hear ครับ
and ค่ะ

being spoken. This is especially prominent in lower and middle classes, but is a general trend. This can be compared to western languages, where adding "Sir" at the end of each sentence when speaking to somebody in authority is becoming less and less common, and already entirely removed in many languages. On another note, there is a trend among the upper and middle classes, especially among younger men, to call each other
, no matter the age difference. This is part of greater age equality in Thailand.

There are no less than three systems for telling time in Thailand. The easiest of the three is the
, encountered primarily in bus and railway schedules. To create an official time, simply affix
นาฬิกา to the number of hours, so that e.g.
is 9AM (09:00) and

is 1PM (13:00).

Things get a little more difficult in the
.  As in the West, the number of the hour runs from 1 to 12, but instead of just AM and PM, the day is divided into four sections (ตอน

(morning), from 6 AM to noon
# บ่าย

(afternoon), from noon to 4 PM
# เย็น

(evening), from 4 PM to 6 PM
# คืน

(night), from 6 PM to 11 PM
